(See photos) **$9.95 for 24 hours Internet--but kept getting booted off after 2 to 5 minutes. The Internet help line Tier 3 folks fixed it after making multiple extended calls each night. **Sleeping / sitting area appeared clean but I found several things on the floor when I first came in: raisin, eyeliner, dental floss container and a metal tag. **Tiny television **Safe in the room, big enough for a laptop with a 14" screen or an SLR camera with a short lens (not big enough for both). Bad: **Only 1 individual serving of decaf coffee (2 regular/ 2 creamer / sugar pkgs.) I used the decaf and both creamers. None were replaced day two or day three. **No disposable plastic bag in the ice bucket so I washed it with shampoo and rinsed it really well before using it. **No "AFFORDABLE" eating places nearby open after 5 p.m. weekdays or anytime on weekend. **Hotel restaurant is $$$. (See MB website) **Room Service also $$$: Breakfast: Corn flakes $7.50; Belgian Waffles $14; Lunch: Cobb Salad $16.50; Kobe Burger $17.50; Dinner: Halibut $30; Pear Salad $9; french fries $4.75 -- PLUS a 15% gratuity, PLUS 3% surcharge, PLUS taxes, PLUS $3.25 delivery charge. I ordered a chicken quesadilla "to go" from the bar and paid more than $15 (before tip). **Lots of homeless, not a place to walk around after dark. I wish there was a "maybe" or "depends" recommendation buttong. I will "recommend" this hotel to a friend with a disclaimer: Get it cheap and don't expect a lot after you get past the beauty of the lobby.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible horrible horrible - bug infested room!”
Reviews.Author: gigmo
Reviews.Content: I made the mistake of staying at this hotel in February 2010, and went to sleep with clear skin, and awoke the following morning with well over 50 bug bites covering my neck, legs, stomach, chest, hips, rear, arms, and back. I sleep facing down so it made sense that the areas with the highest concentration of bites were the parts of my body that were on the bed. The bug bites were so bad that my dermatologist tested me for chicken pox! Thanks to the bug bites, I had to attend court hearings and a wedding covered in unsightly bug bites, endured over a week of physical discomfort, not to mention embarrassment, and spent money on doctors’ visits and medication including antibiotics. Over 3 weeks later, I still have noticeable scars from the worst bites on parts of my body. Unless you want bug bites to be your most lasting souvenir from your visit to LA, I strongly advise that you STAY SOMEWHERE ELSE! What's worse is that the customer service at the hotel could not possibly be worse. Ever since my initial complaint, the hotel has done nothing but avoid taking responsibility by giving me blanket denials that anything happened and shifting the blame to someone else. Despite the hotel’s claim that an alleged "pest inspection" occurred, the hotel has refused to show me a copy of the inspection report (because such reports are “confidential”), but even they claim that the pest control company only checked for bed bugs not fleas (the likely culprit)- how convenient! This hotel should stick to allowing TV and movie crews to film its old-fashioned lobby, and not subject unsuspecting guests to its disgusting, bug-infested rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Elegance”
Reviews.Author: campervanuk
Reviews.Content: A grand hotel with elegant public areas. Large, well fitted rooms.

Reviews.Title: “This hotel was amazing...in the 30s. Stay Away!”
Reviews.Author: BaronessEast
Reviews.Content: As I am sure that this hotel was beautiful and amazing in the 1930s - they haven't redone the rooms since then. I was so disgusted when I saw my room I immediately checked out. The room had a rock hard bed, a 13" color box TV (???), and bolted shut windows overlooking a heavily crowded intersection of 5th street downtown. And I won't even start on the Motel 6 bathroom. PROS: - The lobby and ballroom are nostalgic CONS: - Location is horrible and you have to valet your car - Rooms haven't been updated since the 50s at LEAST - Bed is a rock - TV is ancient - Bathrooms look like they are from project housing

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel - but the location was terrible for us without a car”
Reviews.Author: Auntie033
Reviews.Content: I stayed here over Thanksgiving 2009 and wrote a review when I came home but decided not to post it as I didn't think I was being very objective slating this lovely hotel over it's location. However I have decided to write the review again as I think reading a review like this would have helped me to make a better decision when booking a hotel in LA. This hotel was recommended to me by a friend who had stayed here in 2008. The hotel itself is beautiful and full of history, the bus driver on one of our tours called it a 'world class hotel' The room was big, with 2 single beds and a really comfy armchair and footstool. The front desk staff were very helpful with instructions and directions. We ate on the evening of Thanksgiving in the bar (having raced down to our booked restaurant at LA Live to find it closed ) and the lady serving us was absolutely lovely and the food delicious. It was right beside the metro which was great for getting to Hollywood and Universal. However, beware, we came out the wrong door of the station one evening and it took us 50 minutes to find the hotel, thru some really dodgy areas :-( The huge let-down for me in this hotel was the location, based on the fact that we didn't have a car. As mentioned, the metro was great for Universal and Hollywood, but that's about it. You are stuck in the middle of Downtown, even the bus driver on our tour offered to drop the Biltmore guests in Hollywood as "there is nothing to do around here" We got the number 16 bus out to Century City on our last day and to say it was an uncomfortable ride would be an understatement - we got shouted at when we got on for - lets just say - not fitting the profile of the usual people who travel on this bus so felt very unwelcome, and journey went on forever. When we were finished shopping we got a cab all the way back to Hollywood rather than get on that bus again. We booked a shuttle with the hotel to get back to the airport and it turned up 30 minutes late and then brought us all around the city picking up other people (with a driver that didn't seem to have a clue where he was going) We ended up nearly missing our flight. So in summing up, this is a lovely hotel and if you have a car I would definitely recommend it, however, if you are relying on public transport, I would stay in Hollywood or Santa Monica. And don't use the airport shuttle! This hotel is a 4 out of 5 for me, but I'm afraid i have to knock off a point for the location.

Reviews.Title: “Liked everything”
Reviews.Author: lmw_8
Reviews.Content: We loved the hotel. As everyone has said, architecture and decor are beautiful. We found everyone to be friendly and helpful, our inside room quiet and very comfortable (we don't care about a small tv and never use minibars) and parking at the Pershing Square lot easy. Restaurant in the rotunda was good and the servers were so gracious . This is where I will stay on future visits to LA.

Reviews.Title: “Very Grand in the lobby but not so grand in the rooms”
Reviews.Author: newstead5
Reviews.Content: On arrival our first impression was WOW, all the public area's were very grand and the place was full of history. The rooms however were very dreary. A chunky old TV and a battered bathroom but it was clean and tidy and all that we required. We found the concierge really helpful & friendly but the Reception Team were very frosty and some should practice smiling a little more! Check out there website for deals we paid just $100 a night for the first few nights but then when we had to book and extra night we paid twice that. Loads of hidden costs here as well the Bar was pretty pricey and $40 plus tips to park the hire car per day. Check out the Coffee Shop a few doors down though the guy in there is really helpful if you need any local info.

Reviews.Title: “Wished it was better...”
Reviews.Author: CanadaBuck
Reviews.Content: A lot of these posted reviews all echo similar complaints. Yes, parking is $40 and internet access is $10 - which is truly disappointing considering patrons are paying top dollar for services a seasoned traveler would think was standard. One would hope that some of the money went towards a face-lift in renovating the room decor. Some people may refer to it as classic, while others would say, just plain old. The TV in the room was uh...hmm...small and incredibly out-dated. I understand premium rooms may have flat panel TV's, but the standard room has a TV so small and so old, you would have thought the hotel would be embarrassed to even feature it. I know I was a little embarrassed watching it. I have to admit though, it was a little funny to see. The hotel offers a decent variety with respect to cable channels, but the digital feed was a little choppy at times. But heck, this stuff happens at home too, so I shouldn't complain too much. The level of service was on par of a hotel this size and supposed history. Nothing super but clearly not a flaw. Our room was clean and relatively noise-free, so I cannot relate to other patrons who complained about the thickness of the walls. We did however, smell a lot of marijuana use on our floor. And unfortunately not one day, but a few days. Wait. Is that good or bad??? At least the night manager (James) was kind enough to comp 2 night's of parking. It alleviated some of the disappointment of staying there. Clearly everyone here should take the advice of others and the PR Manager for the hotel by parking at Pershing Square. Clearly a bargain, but shoddy neighborhood, especially at night. Don't park too far from the hotel would be my advice. The only question I leave for the hotel and others to consider is: Why leave these little place cards on the bed each morning about the laundering of linens schedule? My guess is because the hotel is cutting back on services and cannot afford to continue doing such service without passing off the cost to the patron? Then why nickel and dime on the parking, internet, and fridge services? So much hope for a nice stay, but left disappointed. BUYER BEWARE, read up on their hotel services before committing. John Yoo

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Hotel with helpful staff”
Reviews.Author: SingerUk Posted by an OctopusTravel traveler
Reviews.Content: Good hotel with helpful staff. The help the hotel gave with respect to places to see and how to use the public transports system was outstanding. If I had been given the information with respect to the public transport facilities before hand I would not have rented a car..I found driving on the 8 lane highways a nightmare and would not recommend getting around LA by self drive car. We left the car in the parking lot across the street and took the metro and bus

Reviews.Title: “Other reviews are mixed - mine is positive!”
Reviews.Author: EAZELIFF
Reviews.Content: This was the first time I had ever booked a hotel using Priceline. I bid $125 for a downtown hotel and the Biltmore accepted it, and it entitled me to Club privileges. I thought my room on the 9th floor was beautiful, in an understated, elegant way. I like the sturdy chair and cut glass bathroom doorknob, out of another era. The sdtreet noise was rather apparent, but not really a problem. The health club area is beautiful, with the elaborate mosaic tilework and brass railings around the pool - looks like the movie star set used to go swimming here. It was evident that some cost cutting measures had taken place - most of the keys were msiing form the lockers and there was no attendant present. I agree with another reviewer that what really makes this place are the ornate public areas and photo exhibits. I wanted to stay downtown to attend concerts at nearby Walt Disney Concert Hall. The last evening I heard pianist Emmanuel Ax and cellist Yo Yo Ma. Wonderful. SO, having never stayed in downtown LA before, I ended up having quite a good time! ( I was not driving, having arrived by subway, so did not have to contend with parking charges. )

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful hotel; sloppy housekeeping”
Reviews.Author: rugglesruggiero
Reviews.Content: I have stayed at the Biltmore a number of time because of its convenience - and because it is one of the most beautiful hotels in Los Angeles. I was disappointed this trip, however, by the sloppy housekeeping that I found when I checked into my room. The lamps on the table near the bed had visible dust bunnies on them - and the sink and bath both had little strands of hair from either the prior guest or the housekeeping staff, and the sink did not look very clean. This was the first time I encountered such poor housekeeping, but hope it's not a sign of staff cutbacks and declining service. When I checked in they told me that their room service had been cut back from 24 hours to 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. For early morning travelers who like to have breakfast before they leave, that's very disappointing.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel, a few let downs”
Reviews.Author: casey+jenny
Reviews.Content: Was really looking forward to staying at this hotel as it has so much history, the foyer is amazing all marble and its kept nice and clean, the reception staff were friendly but found the conciege Very RUDE! i think he really didn't want to be there and wanted to be on a catwalk instead!! not very friendly or helpful! We got updraded to a suite and access to the club lounge through my work so made the most of the breakfast and canapas in the evening! was nice a relaxing in there and was only next door to out bedroom! room was very spacious! with a very small bathroom!! furnature Dated with a very large T.V but i supose modern funature would not look right in a hotel like this! Room service was good and the the cheese cake was amazing! Location is not the best the subay is near the hotel but we found this area quite dodgy at night so might be best to get taxi's in the evenings we got lost after getting off the subway in the pitch black!! Not sure if i would go back to this hotel because of the loctation but its worth seeing for all the history of it.

Reviews.Title: “Has some good points”
Reviews.Author: Melb_Couple
Reviews.Content: I've stayed in hundreds of 'quality' hotels and I think this is perhaps the hardest one I could have picked to write a review about; which probably explains the mixed reviews this hotel receives on this site. There is no argument that the Biltmore truely is a beautiful, grand old hotel. When you walk into the lobby it's hard not to be impressed with all that you see before you. It's like stepping back to a bygone era of elegance and refinement. BUT... if you want to stay in a hotel that has the history, the elegance and the beauty of the Biltmore you have to just accept that your room isn't going to fitted out with modern furnishings and the layout of the bathroom isn't going to make the most of the space. Like most hotels, the Biltmore has rooms of varying standards. Those who are fortunate enough to enjoy a stay on the top two floors (floors 10 and 11) will no doubt be scratching their heads at the reviews left by those who stay on the lower floors. These are their Club Rooms and they have more soundproofing on the walls and windows. The windows also have quality drapes that help keep the sound and light from outside down to a minimum. The furnishings in these rooms is a little grander and the carpets a bit newer. Floors 1 to 9 are the cheaper floors and it shows. They have timber plantation shutters on the windows that do very little to keep out noise and light. There are no drapes at all. The placement of the bed is 10-12 inches from the window, which only compounds the noise and light problems. There is no soundproofing between the rooms and although I didn't hear a great deal of noise from the room nextdoor to mine, I believe this has been an issue for some people. You won't find modern furnishings this hotel, instead you find simple but elegant furniture that is in keeping with the ear of the hotel. Our room, on the 9th floor, and all of the others I saw during our stay, were furnished with a desk, a large comfortable bed, a chair, a large set of drawers and a LCD tv. Our room had a huge closet but I understand this may vary in some of the rooms. The bathroom feels a little cramped but only because of the huge original old tub. Remember the days when tubs were deep enough that you could soak up to your neck and long enough that you could lay back with your legs stretched out? These are the wonderful kind of tubs you get at the Biltmore and they are devine after a long day of sightseeing in L.A.! Yes, you need to pay extra for wifi access in your room. It's $9.95 for 24 hours, but how many good quality hotels provide it free in a standard room booking? Not too many that I know of. In my experience you only find free wifi (and usually breakfast too) on offer in the budget hotels. It's how they pull in customers. There are so many great things about staying at the Biltmore. The food in the hotel restaurants is good and not overly expensive, the location is fantastic - there is a subway on the next corner and the staff were all friendly and helpful but I think the very best thing about staying here is wandering around the public areas of the hotel. There are numerous old photographs that are well worth seeing, including many taken during some of the Academy Awards presentations held at the hotel, and some magnificent ballrooms that are works of art. There was a wedding reception being held in one of the ballrooms during our stay and the room looked stunning. We stayed at the hotel for 5 days and for the most part, I was really happy with the hotel. It's an experience I won't soon forget and I feel I'm lucky to have stayed in the same hotel as so many famous Hollywood stars from years ago. However, I wouldn't stay there again. I say that only because of the windows. If they removed the shutters (or even put them on the outside which would keep the same look) and put up blockout drapes in ALL the rooms it would make a huge difference and I'd be recommending this hotel to everyone as a 'must stay' location. If you can afford the extra dollars, book a room on the top two floors. You won't be sorry you did!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful historic lobby and common area. But, rooms unremarkable and a bit noisy”
Reviews.Author: streamvista
Reviews.Content: We stayed here because we were attending a wedding at the same hotel. The hotel itself is beautiful and is practically a tourist attraction with its ornate ceilings and historic features. Overall, it has a lot of character. It was the perfect place for a wedding and looks gorgeous in photos. The pros: Downtown location Historic character and charm Fairly priced Larger room Has full service gym and a pool The Cons: Rooms are old and the heating/cooling, hot water, and insulation is not as good as a modern hotel. Noise from the street was audible in the room (in fact, they had a pair of ear plugs on the night stand) Not particularly luxurious in the room itself; but sufficient and clean. Hallway seemed a bit worn and the lighting was dull. OVERALL: For the money, I'd say this is a good deal for downtown Los Angeles. The hotel has a lot of character and, in my opinion, it means you will not forget your stay here as easily as a typical chain hotel. However, I am a bit disappointed that the rooms were not remodeled better and that the hotel has not resolved the issue of noise being audible in rooms. I've stayed in other historic hotels that have not had this issue (i.e. Reed House, Chattanooga, TN) and were remodeled better. So, I think there are ways for this hotel to improve itself. That said, price paid to value received was fair. So, I can recommend this to travelers. RECOMMENDATION: To avoid the exorbitant parking charges ($45/nt), I highly recommend parking at the Pershing Square garage. It is only $16. So, you save a lot of money in parking. Also, since it is across the street, it is not far from the hotel and fairly convenient.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible service, outdated policies, and a major disappointment.”
Reviews.Author: MrsHeter
Reviews.Content: I've traveled all over the world and never have I left a hotel review. I'm easy to please and enjoy the little stuff in life. I expected big things from the famous hotel and they failed to deliver even slighty. The only thing it has going is the history and gorgeous facad. Customer service: lame. I called in advance to get connected to the conceirge. They disconnected me twice and So I figured I'd send an email asking my question about theater tickets. They failed to return the email entirely. It took four attempts to get the answer. Checking in the clerk was a bit snotty and unhappy in general. I was in awe of the building but then quickly in awe (not in a good way) of our room. Decorations ok but outdated tiny tv, no fridge, no microwave, no robe, no minibar? Bed, desk, chair. They also put us in room 666 which maybe explains the lack of attention? They also charge a stupid fee for Internet use. Huh? What is this 1997?it's 2010 and Internet is everywhere. Finally parking was a shocking $45 and I'm from this area so I knew it would be high. I'm writing this while still checked in the hotel. I'm hoping they redeem themselves.

Reviews.Title: “Classic Grand Hotel at a great value”
Reviews.Author: stuckintraffic
Reviews.Content: We needed a downtown LA hotel for one night, but we also wanted something unique. LA has a lot of unique hotels, but few as Grand as the Biltmore. What sealed the deal was a two fold deal we got on the room. First the regular rate they were running at the time was excellent for this level of hotel, and they have a "72 Hour" rate, if you book within 72 hours of arrival the rate is discounted further, couldn't beat it. As far as the hotel: 1. This hotel is a monument to an earlier time when hotels were grand. The Academy Awards, Emmys, and Grammys have all been held here, in addition to several after-parties. The night we stayed the Dalai Lama was having a press conference in one of the ballrooms. The history and grandeur of the hotel is unmatched. The public rooms, lobby, etc are in perfect condition despite their age. It is very impressive and enjoyable. 2. The rooms themselves seem to get some mixed reviews here. Over the years of using sites like TripAdvisor I have learned to read between the lines of reviews and rely more on user photos than what is actually said. People comment on how historic this hotel is and then complain how small the bathrooms are. (Sorry, that comes with the territory in historic older buildings). Yes, they are small, but they are amazingly well kept. I marvel at the little things like the original doorknobs throughout that are still used and look great. Or the real porcelain tubs that are in perfect condition. Or the solid marble floors, the 10" floor molding, and on and on. These rooms are historic and in amazing condition. The carpets looked brand new, the entire room was immaculate. Some complain that the rooms are plain, again they are beautiful and appear to be set up as they would have been years ago when this Grand Dame was built. The only complaint about the room is though the beds are very comfortable, and all the linens were very clean, the thread count on the sheets did not match up to the quality of the room. The TV was a brand new 42" flat screen, very nice. The best way to describe the furniture in the room is "regal". This furniture could have been in the presidential suite and not looked out of place. Some also complain about paper thin walls, this one baffles me. I know when this hotel was built, and these walls are "not" thin. We did not here a thing from any adjacent room or from the hallway. You must realize though that this is a downtown hotel in LA, you do hear some traffic noise. 3. Pool area is spectacular, a classic. But understand again what that means.....it is not large, it does not have water slides, etc. It is a pool from a day gone by that does not show it's age. Again, interested and fascinated by the details, the steamer chaise lounges are something you would have found on the Titanic, but look brand new. There is a jacuzzi (that is absolutely tiny in today's standards but again in perfect condition), a wet sauna, a dry sauna, and a very sizable work out room with high end equipment. 4. We stayed on the Club floor which entitled us to access to the Club Lounge. We took advantage of the evening snacks and beverages, and then again had breakfast there. Both had an excellent selection, not extensive, but plenty to choose from and very good quality. The scones with French cream were amazing. The other highlight for us (diehard Beatles fans that we are) is that near the elevators on the Club floor is the door to the Heliport on the roof. This is the exit the Beatles had to use to escape the crowds in the lobby below when they stayed here. (The Dalai Lama, the Beatles, and Walt Disney, among others.......how did we rate to stay here?) 5. The restaurants all look awesome, though very high end, but we did not get a chance to try them. 6. We were only there one night, so we did not have much need for service from the hotel staff. But the check in was quick and seemless. The valet was extremely friendly and accommodating. When we arrived, we were going to check in and then immediately leave for dinner. They had no problem holding our car aside for us, even though they are working with a very confined mid-city location. 7. Overall what did I love? Original and well maintained public spaces-I felt like royalty. Original double hung windows, door knobs, moldings, light fixtures, and furniture that take you back in time, but don't look any older than when they were installed. Perfect downtown location. Great service when we needed it. The sense of history and grandeur. 8. What didn't I like? The quality of the bed linens (they were clean, just very low thread count) The $45/night valet charge. (But honestly, it is downtown LA, parking everywhere is at a premium). The fact that we were not told that access to the Club Lounge is limited to 2 guests/room and any additional guests are $25/person. The food was good but not substantial enough for an additional fee. Overall, a fantastic stay in a historic hotel, we loved it.

Reviews.Title: “Great old hotel, yet old part looks a little too obvious...”
Reviews.Author: timmi9
Reviews.Content: This was the last stop of our trip and I had a good expectation of this hotel. The lobby and restaurants are beautiful, the location is excellent (walking distance to Staples Center) and the hotel had a very classic feel. The fitness centre was the best I saw in the USA. The only downsides to this place were that the rooms were a little run down and the staff didn't tell me that they charged $50 for phone use before I could access the phone in my room (which was reimbursed after I arrived home), even though I only called using a international phone card. I might have been unaware of this policy, but when travelling on a budget you can't afford these things to happen. Also we unfortunately had a wedding party stay next door and they weren't told to keep it down until about 3am. But that isn't the hotel's fault, just be aware that it can happen. Overall the place was adequate but I left the hotel feeling like I didn't get value for money. PS- the ice skating at pershing square behind the hotel over the holidays was great fun.

Reviews.Title: “Good Rose Bowl stay”
Reviews.Author: Waggy16
Reviews.Content: We stayed here over New Year's Eve to watch the Oregon Ducks in the Rose Bowl. We parked across the street at the Pershing Square parking garage. This was only $15 a day and we highly recommend it. Our hotel room was clean and but on the smaller side. The hotel lobby is impressive and we had a couple of drinks at the hotel bar before heading to dinner. Pricy but good! The hotel is right across the street from the redline Metro stop - perfect for getting to Pasadena for the Rose Bowl. Why would you drive when the train runs right to Pasadena? Even though Oregon lost the game, we enjoyed our stay at the Biltmore and we stay there again next year (if the Ducks are in the Rose Bowl again).

Reviews.Title: “Not great, but pretty good”
Reviews.Author: Papa_Sid
Reviews.Content: My son and I stayed 3 days while attending the BCS Championship game at the Rose Bowl. The Biltmore is an old (and old-fashioned) facility. Seems well maintained. Rooms are larger than what you get in more "modern" units and very well appointed. Only drawback to me was that the wiring doesn't comfortably accommodate all of the electronic gadgets we travel with nowadays. Service (bell captain, concierge, front desk, etc.) was all A1++. Tried two of their 4 restaurants and both were good.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, lacking service”
Reviews.Author: TrippySydney
Reviews.Content: Everywhere I went, if I said I was staying at the Biltmore, the general reaction was, Wow. And wow it was from the grandness of the interiors. But the hotel does look very very old and many areas would look even better with a change of carpets, fixtures or some new tiles/flooring. It looks painfully neglected in parts. My most severe criticism of the hotel however, is the service. Namely that of the doormen/bellmen/valet. They were practically nonexistent! When they were around, they stood rooted neither greeting you nor helping to open the doors. Really appalling. Considering I usually left/entered the hotel 4-6 times a day, this soon became very apparent. It didn't feel like a five-star hotel at all. Check in: fast, efficient, polite. Room: The bed was extremely comfy but otherwise the furnishings and in-room amenities were nothing much to shout about. Size was average. Though most rooms are supposed to have an in-room safe, mine didn't. So I used the Reception's safe which was 24 hours and free. My room also didn't have a mini bar at all. How very odd. Bathroom is tiny and two people is one too many. The bathtub had been painted over with white paint which was flaking and felt awful under the feet. But water pressure and temperature consistently GREAT! One of the best I've ever had. View: My room had not much of a view - well that of other rooms of the hotel as I was staying in a 'U' shaped block. The old 1930s photos in the corridors are quite interesting if a little spooky in 'The Shining' movie kind of way. Location: Good as it was next to Pershing Square Metro station. But if you wander a few blocks away it can get a little questionable especially at night.

Reviews.Title: “Impressive”
Reviews.Author: picture_of_innocence
Reviews.Content: Enjoyed our stay at the Millennium Biltmore, LA. Room was very large, massive walk in wardrobe, great beds/pillows. A hotel from a by-gone era, it is still very impressive, check out the lobby, the swimming pool, a hotel steeped in history. Valet is very expensive ($40 per night) but there are other nearby options.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible Terrible Terrible Hotel I have ever stayed”
Reviews.Author: hsbd
Reviews.Content: This is most terrible hotel we have ever stayed. Even the motel's bathroom is more decent that this one's. The only thing looks good is its lobby. Don't mention its sound insulation the wall is paper thin and the roach is running in the closet. What a nightmare!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Don't bother”
Reviews.Author: TheAusCouple
Reviews.Content: Like many others we were seduced by the history and beautiful photos. The lobby is beautiful but its all down hill from there. The room itself is okay but the bathrooms are terrible. The Holiday Inn we stayed in before was better. The shower has two speeds - off and fire hose. Result = flooded bathroom everytime you have a shower. As usual, the more a hotel charges, the more stingy they are. In this case that means no room safe, internet $9.95 (per appliance mind you - if you have a laptop and a iPhone that means $20). Bed was a king and comfy but for the money you can do a lot better. Location was good.

Reviews.Title: “CAUTION!! CAUTION!! CAUTION!!”
Reviews.Author: WillyRollTide
Reviews.Content: Rather than waste your time reading a long review about how horrible this hotel is, I thought it would be better just to tell you straight up that unless you plan on sleeping in the beautiful lobby, I would stay some where else. The rooms are in fact as bad as everyone else said they were. Through today, I have spent 42 nights in a hotel in 2009. This crap hole room ranks dead last and take into consideration that I was in a rustic fishcamp motel back in July.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel but bad location and snobby staff.”
Reviews.Author: Kenji_Ball
Reviews.Content: Its a good 30-60 minutes away from Hollywood, the Grove, Uniervsal Studios, Beverlly Hills, Citadel and Venice Beach. The hotel is very "posh" and upper class. The lobby and gym are good but the rooms are outdated. Not a great place to stay as a tourist, I felt unsafe walking around late at night. The front desk was quite rude and unhelpful but the 2 gentlemen working as the conceirge's were fantastic. Not as good as the pictures make it look. They overcharge everything in the hotel... and internet costs $10/day.

Reviews.Title: “excellent hotel even with kids”
Reviews.Author: bobbyali
Reviews.Content: We stayed in this hotel for the thanksgiving week and we loved it, attaention readers do not listen to the bad reviews on this hotel as the are just opinions not facts. we had a great time, we enjoyed the pool with the children the only flaw was that valet parking was 40 dollars a night and you need to tip but you can stay across the street at pershing square for 15 bucks a night that was convinient. other than that it was beutifull if any one goes to la i will recommend only this hotel to stay at....

Reviews.Title: “lovely hotel, very posh but a bit noisey.”
Reviews.Author: murph36
Reviews.Content: Stayed here straight off the plane from dublin. Very posh hotel and was given the option of a quiet room or one with a view. choose a view. mistake!!! should have realised when there was earplugs beside the bed!! Other then this the hotel is first class all the way, food is great. staff are A1.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous Hotel, why stay anywhere else in downtown LA ?”
Reviews.Author: kanga5
Reviews.Content: Recently I had the pleasure to stay at the Biltmore again after 30years. This time with my 26year old daughter. We loved it. Our room, although facing walls, was spacious clean and comfortable.James on the concierge desk was extremely helpful with all requests. Was so pleased it was as lovely as I remembered it all those years ago. Would definately stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel in LA”
Reviews.Author: AshfromBrisbane
Reviews.Content: This was a great hotel. We were impressed by the grand interior and really liked our room. We stayed 3 nights and it was clean and comfortable. The free internet in the lobby was a definite plus. The Concierge, James, was gracious and helpful - best concierge we met in our three week stay in USA. The best thing about this hotel is the location. It is literally across the road from Pershing Square station and you can catch the (extremely easy to use and very clean) metro pretty much anywhere you want to go (except Santa Monica). It was the perfect base for our LA trip.

Reviews.Title: “Classic Hotel”
Reviews.Author: jackalope76
Reviews.Content: The hotel is amazing from the time you step in the doors. The original detail of the hotel is well preserved, and is really something to see. Very few once glamorous hotels have been able to retain the charm that this one has. The service is somewhat lacking, but the rooms are nice and spacious. A car is a must if you plan on heading west to the beach. A cab would be super expensive from downtown. I loved just walking around the lobby and ground floor to look at the impressive architecture and finishes in the building. Definitely a value considering how nice the hotel is.

Reviews.Title: “Grandiose Hotel with Breathtaking Public Areas”
Reviews.Author: GordonA
Reviews.Content: Chose this hotel from illustrations in Brochures because of its history and grandiose appearance. I certainly wasn't disappointed as the Reception area, Lobby and other Public Areas are breathtaking in their style and decor, built in an era when costs weren't the driving force. Contrary to other reviews the bedroom was large and tastefully furnished although the TV could have been more modern in a five star hotel. The Breakfast was of excellent standard as was dinner in the Asian/Japanese restaurant. In both restaurants sevice was prompt and courteous. Hovever the hotel is in the Financial District area of L.A. and therfore there is a lack of choice for dining outside the hotel. The adjacent Metro station was ideal for visiting Hollywood and its attractions, although I found Hollywood a big disappointment and susprisingly 'tacky'.

Reviews.Title: “Classic hotel retains its charm”
Reviews.Author: GregChapelHill
Reviews.Content: I had not been to downtown Los Angeles in many years and had never stayed at the Biltmore, so I didn't know quite what to expect. The building has a fascinating history (Academy Awards and all that), and it's fun just to browse around. My room was surprisingly large for such an old hotel, and it had the usual amenities that you would expect in a modern hotel. The exception was a lack of electrical outlets, but I guess that would be hard to change. The staff was helpful, and my breakfast was enjoyable, although pricey. The location is good for all of the entertainment venues nearby as well as two excellent restaurants within two blocks to the left coming out of the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “An extraordinary hotel”
Reviews.Author: aussieAl_61
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Biltmore for 3 nights during a 3 week West Coast trip. I was able to get some rooms at a good rate online. My stay was nothing less than superb. The central location is probably as good as you can get anywhere in LA. The service, the rooms and the quality of the hotel were outstanding. I, and all my party, sat in the loby at checkout time not wanting to leave. The building is exquisite. We made lots of use of the gym and pool which was included in the tariff. The two rooms we had were large and the beds and pillows were the most comfortable any of us had experienced previously. The bathrooms are little on the small side but nicely appointed. Can't

Reviews.Title: “Not too shabby”
Reviews.Author: FlipperGirl
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Biltmore. It's definitely like stepping into the past and no Hotel chain could today try to recreate the grandiose, charm and style of the lobby, open hallways, crown molding, stairways with banisters that aren't enclosed in concrete, etc. It's very cool just entering the place. Overall, my room was "just OK". Nothing spectacular, but nothing too negative (except the lame TV) to complain about enough to really tell someone else not to stay here. The carpet in the hallways, while worn and a bit stained, doesn't look as tired and dirty as it did "charming". My room was 54something. It was a winding walk to the elevators. The hallways can be like mazes, but that's cool to me. The window in my room could be opened and with its big wooden panes, it felt like grandma's house! My room was basic and simple. Bed comfortable. Good pillows. The TV in the armoire seemed straight from 1990. No kidding. But, it came with cable, a working remote, and at least was in color -- it was just it was a bit far away from the bed and probably a 17" 'er. The bathroom was small, slightly dingy, but still, had character hard to recreate. Not much space to put your toiletries on, though. Towels were pretty dated. Hairdryer...shampoos, etc. all provided. I appreciated the updated cooling system and generally crank it to create "white noise" to mask outside noises -- I could still hear street noise and what sounded like the beeps of a backing up trash truck occasionally thorughout the night, though. I found the staff to be professional and helpful. However, when I did get to my room I found it odd that the chair & ottoman were shoved up against the bed blocking the one nightstand on one side of the bed and there was a silly roll-away cot set up in the free open space where the chair should be. I had to call down to the front desk to make sure the cot wasn't something they thought i requested and especially something I would be paying extra for (which resulted at first in some confusion that I WANTED a cot to be brought up). After she finally understood that I didn't want the cot right there in my room, they sent someone within 20 minutes to come get it. Kinda weird, but only a minor inconvenience. The price was fine. Parking is valet only and a whopping $40/day. But, this is a city. It is a city that sleeps though and if you are from out of town, there's not much going on in Downtown LA during the weekend like you find in other major US cities. However, if for some reason you take the subway it is close by and other attractions, shopping, and Starbucks are not that far away.

Reviews.Title: “Staff can't handle this place”
Reviews.Author: baangeles
Reviews.Content: checked in at 10:30 PM Saturday. Car line to park. Valet attendants extremley rude, and for 40$ a night. No self parking. Rude forgetful front desk people. Couldn't explain where to find a self park garage. Said " I'll give you a map". After checking in and getting keys. I was asked is there anything else? Yeah how about that map! Pershing garage accross the street 13$ My non-smoking room had no smoke only smelled like it. TV looks like it came from Goodwill. Power went out when my wife was blowdrying her hair. Go somewhere else. Just walk through on your way to the Hilton.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely historical hotel, good location”
Reviews.Author: newyork2007
Reviews.Content: Friends had said...dont stay in downtown! However we were very pleased with your location, hotel itself was lovely! The rooms were a bit dated....good do with redecorating! We tried the sushi restaurant and it was lovely....fresh....not very busy though. The wine etc in the bar was well priced. The concriege were very helpfull! Enjoyed our stay, didnt think LA was that amazing though, would not rush back.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous Hotel, I felt like a dancing aristo-cat!”
Reviews.Author: cambridgeTravelor
Reviews.Content: Gorgeous lobby and restaurant/bar area. Pretty pool too to splash around in. Room was huge, and I was on a non-smoking floor.

Reviews.Title: “Interesting Hotel”
Reviews.Author: MelbournePerry
Reviews.Content: We stayed 7 nites in total in the Billitmore hotel during our recent trip to US. We were given a good room for our first 4 nites, thereafter we left for San Fran & Vegas & returned for 1 nite. The room they gave us was ordinary , The room was small & the sink was clogging every time the tap was opended. We returned for another 2 nites & this time were given a fantastic room. What you need to know when checking in is to ask for a room with a safe as all rooms do not have safes, you should also ask housekeeping for bathrobes plus slipons as they are not provided unless asked. You shouls also ask for shower caps. Good thing is they do not charge you for these items. There is no fridge in the room & if you request one is cost you $10 US a day. The hotel itself has character & history attached to it, It is situated in the down town.. The only problem is during week ends the whole place is empty as all the office's are closed. The staff are friendly & helpful. There was a good restaurant serving meditarrean food & the prices were reasonable, however when we returned after our trip to Vegas they had closed this restauarnt & shifted it to the lobby. They had a new menu & food was average with high price attached to it. The hotel has a wonderful bar. Perera-Melbourne Australia

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel”
Reviews.Author: LINLEE7524
Reviews.Content: This is a beautiful hotel. I have always stayed at the downtown Marriot and the Westin Bonaventure on past trips for work, and they don't hold a candle to the Biltmore. The lobby is grand and inviting, the rooms beautifully appointed - my room on the 10th floor) was a bit small, but I loved the hotel. Tried the Japanese restaurant in the hotel for sushi, and it was delicious. The amenties for those on the Club level (my company has an arrangement where we are all booked there) has appetizers and wine every night, as well as continental breakfast in the am for free. Never tried the breakfast, but loved the appetizers and wine. There was generally one hot appetizer, and a cheese, salami/deli meets, and cracker tray. They had delicious mini Indian samosas with a curry potato and peas mixture inside that was heavenly. I will absolutely stay there for an future trips.

Reviews.Title: “Good service, a bit dated”
Reviews.Author: InLovewithThailand
Reviews.Content: While I requested a non-smoking room due to a serious allergy to smoke, we were placed on a smoking floor that just happened to have a group of people smoking in the hallway rather than in their rooms. We entered the room, which was spacious, but soon the smoke began to waft under the door and I called to be moved to a new room. They were very congenial and sent someone up right away to move us to a non-smoking floor/room. The new room was a bit smaller, but still nice. The bathroom fixtures showed the most amount of wear, but the best was mostly comfortable and the air conditioning worked well. We order room service late at night and for breakfast and were pleased with the quality of the food and timeliness of the delivery. Would stay here again--though the rooms do seem a bit pricey for their quality. Of course, the hotel has many amenities and is a huge property, which accounts for some of the price. I was also quite pleased that they were very generous with their late check-out policy. We got several extra hours at no cost. Thank you, Millennium Biltmore!

Reviews.Title: “Like stepping back in time”
Reviews.Author: salchipapa
Reviews.Content: Nice hotel with historic touches at each corner. Rooms can be on the smaller side but also larger than normal which are beautifully appointed. Some renovation is in order to repair chipped paint here or there but these shortcomings add to the charm. Each time I stay there, I am reminded of its history and prominence. On the last visit I had a chance encounter with Bill Clinton in the lobby after a swim.

Reviews.Title: “Grand old hotel in the middle of downtown LA”
Reviews.Author: teddychan
Reviews.Content: The Millennium Biltmore is a great place to stay for people who enjoy traditional big old hotels. It takes up a city block by itself. The service is excellent, the rooms are large, the location is hard to beat. Finding convenient parking is a challenge especially considering there are some not-so-great neighborhoods in the area. The room corridors can be a bit confusing.

Reviews.Title: “Event location more than hotel”
Reviews.Author: queenarmadillo
Reviews.Content: I was absolutely in love with the look of this hotel. It is gorgeous, the rooms are comfy and clean, and it really feels like you are getting to stay in part of the history of LA. The price was very reasonable for the quality of the hotel. BUT The day we arrived there was some kind of MASSIVE event being hosted there (maybe a talent show). The whole place was crowded with teenagers, and I really do mean packed. We walked into very tired (and grumpy) from our journey to a very loud and packed lobby and could barely see the check in desk through the crowd of teens coming and going. There was also a herd of people about 6 deep waiting for the elevators. I have been to hotel/conference centers etc. before, but have never previously felt like my enjoyment of a hotel was so severely impacted by its other activities. No the hotel shouldn't be expected to babysit its guests, but equally it does need to take responsibility for the comfort of all guests. Things that could have been done to improve our stay would particularly have included letting use use the service elevator to get to the room with our bags as we clearly couldnt fight our way into the standard elevators with them in the crowd, or implementing some kind of queueing system or reserving one carriage for guests not involved in the event. It would also have been nice if one of the staff had informed the teens when their behaviour was unreasonable (e.g. there was a group of boys practicing their drumming routine in the lobby the entire time we were checking in, and I couldn't believe a) that they thought it was appropriate in a public place, or b) that the staff didn't realise that this might be unpleasant for other guests and put a stop to it). I initialy thought this may be a one off incident, but the next day the lobby was in similar chaos, and the talent competition had gone and been replaced with some kind of graduation party, so I really dont understand why the hotel wasn't better equipped to handle these situations. Given the scale of the event and the impact that it had on our quiet enjoyment of our hotel room, I actually think that the hotel should have put up a warning about the talent event on its website for these dates, as it really isn't something you expect and does seriously affect other guests looking for a quiet place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “The most under rated hotel in Los Angeles”
Reviews.Author: lucyl0ve
Reviews.Content: I had no idea what to expect of the Biltmore but my god, did it go above and beyond my expectations. The building is simply stunning and is rich with old Hollywood history, this is where the Oscars started after all! The staff were incredible, the in house restaurants were great, the beds were comfy and the rooms clean. I have no idea why it doesn't sit on par with the Chateau Marmont, perhaps it's because of the slightly seedy downtown area, the Marmont is beautiful but having spent time in a couple of different rooms there they are really nothing too spectacular and very similar to some of the old apartment buildings in Hollywood. Although downtown LA is still up and coming it really is getting there, just walk a block and a half from the Biltmore to Bottega Louie a fairly new upscale deli, restaurant and market, not only can you enjoy the food but it'll give you a glimpse of just where downtown is heading. The only downfall- PARKING $45 a night!!! I beleive this is due to the fact they have very few parking spaces and don't actually want you to park there. There is a parking structure across the street for just $5 though.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible rooms”
Reviews.Author: garfieldvk
Reviews.Content: I read the reviews of this hotel and many gave a descent response so i decided to take this hotel. 1. PARKING- NEVER park in the hotel unless you are fine in spending 40 $ a night. Alternate option - park across the street for 15 dollars for the whole day. 2. The hotel entrance and lobby is awesome but are you going to stay in the lobby?? NO, so about hte room.. The room was terrible. I can find motel rooms better than this. Ancient TV was kept and not enough seating. It has not refrigerator. No proper plug points. They have extension cord ?? can you believe it? Very dated health club and no free internet.

Reviews.Title: “Great historical Hotel for the movie buff”
Reviews.Author: ngalgano
Reviews.Content: A hotel that has featured in over 100 movies - including the revitalisation pool from Cocoon. If you like Art Deco and a hotel with a history [hosting Oscars and US Presidents] then this is the hotel for you. Conceirge James Russell is a valuable asset for the hotel and very helpful and accomodating. He is very proud of his hotel. The Hotel is magnificant, if a little away from the throbing heart of LA being in the commercial centre of LA but transport is plentiful and this should not disuade anyone form booking a night at this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Definitely . . . pretty good, but not great”
Reviews.Author: EastBayTraveler
Reviews.Content: I've stayed here several times for work. The pros: good location to Bunker Hill/Arco Towers area; friendly desk staff; clean rooms; Club Level breakfast is not bountiful but pretty tasty and very convenient; nice bar. No real "con," but a variety of things that make stays not that comfortable: fair amount of street noise; beds are a little above average for hotels, but not great; doors and fixtures are old-looking/feeling; small bathrooms; older TVs. I think it's better than Checkers, but it's close. Downtown LA needs a great hotel. This one is pretty good.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel in the Downtown area”
Reviews.Author: esquimer
Reviews.Content: I was pleasantly surprised when checking in to this hotel. Eventhough we only stayed one night, the hotel was elegant and provided excellent service. We ordered room service, since we arrived late and the food was excellent, room service was fast and very courteous. I have nothing to say but wonderful comments about this hotel. Room was large with great view of the downtown area, comfortable beds with nice linens and great toiletries.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful elegance, great location at a nice price.”
Reviews.Author: Konehead
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a nice hotel near the LA convention center as I wanted to attend the American Numismatic Association's World's Fair of Money. I also wanted a central location to allow for some sightseeing. We decided to extend our stay from 2 to 3 nights after seeing how beautiful the hotel was, and I got a cheaper price through hotel reservations than from one of the online booking agencies! In addition to a free concert in next door Pershing Square, we had easy access to the LA metro (I know, who knew). We had a great time exploring Hollywood, China Town and Olvera Street by bus and metro, and ended up by taking the train out of Union Station for our next port of call.

Reviews.Title: “Grand Hotel, different version of LA”
Reviews.Author: twostar
Reviews.Content: If you can get a good rate on this hotel (there have been some incredible deals online) - you should go for it. It's a classy, historic hotel. Like most reviewers have noted it's a little dated, and doesn't have modern luxury features (i.e. older tvs, average sheets, no luxury bathroom products) but the loveliness of the building makes up for it. The service is as good as any place I've stayed, the bar and restaurants are in beautiful rooms, and the building is a landmark in the downtown area. If the W is more your style, this is not the place for you. If you don't mind sacrificing some modern luxuries for a bit of history and charm, this is a great place. You can park for $15/day in the lot kitty-corner to the hotel, and there's a nice park across the street that has concerts and outdoor movies showing throughout the summer - free and fun! Also walk a few blocks to Bottega Louie for coffee/breakfast - excellent place to eat!

Reviews.Title: “Highlight of our trip”
Reviews.Author: JasonMurrihy
Reviews.Content: Recently honeymooned from Australia - we stayed at the Biltmore for 4 nights - and found the experience absolutely breathtaking. Staff were courteous and friendly - and the rooms were generous in size (compared with New York). Very old world Hollywood. If you have to stay downtown LA - look no further than this hotel - the beauty is something to behold. (and home of the Black Dahlia cocktail) Jason

Reviews.Title: “Nice Surprise”
Reviews.Author: VisaliaSimpleLife
Reviews.Content: My partner and I arrived late on a Wednesday night. I appreciated the valet area which is off the street. Check in was quick and efficient and after a long drive I appreciated the friendly staff. The room was large enough for two people. We did not go into the bar area but it looked like something I would definitely check into on our next visit. I did venture out for a quick walk to find a convenience store. At 10pm I did not find anything open. The location of this hotel was very convenient for the purpose of our stay which was to attend a court appearance 2 blocks away for an immigration case. That morning, we checked out by 7:30am and had the hotel hold our bags in the front and left our car at the hotel. We were done by noon and retrieved our bags and car and was on our way. I would like to stay at the Biltmore again. Very cool hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Classic Hotel that needs a few better employees”
Reviews.Author: NYCtravelboy
Reviews.Content: Stayed in this hotel for two nights and found it breathtaking. The public areas are magnificent. Beautifully restored and elegant. When was the last time you wandered around the hotel? Here you will want to. I applaud them for keeping the property so polished. My room was very large with a roomy living room section. A huge walk-in closet; separate vanity section and long entrance hallway. The windows do open (which I loved) and unlike other posters, provided no outside noise to keep me up. The way the floors are laid out, you can have a very long walk from the one set of elevators to your room. I didn't mind myself, but if you are a guest with problems walking ask ahead of time. The gym was good quality and the pool area was memorable. They restore the 1920s pool and bathing area to great effect. Also locker rooms, showers, sauna and steam available. Nice feature and all complimentary for guests. Most of the staff was wonderful: The parking valets, the bellman, the houseman, the waiters at Smeraldis (a nice restaurant in the lobby) and the man at the coffee stand were always cheery, friendly and accomodating. The problem is the front desk staff and the club lounge employees. I went to the front desk three times total. Each time no other guest was there. Each time no one looked up to acknowledge me. No one ever offered a smile, a greeting, anything. Now they don't need to become my friend, but it can be pricey to stay there. Checking in, my clerk mumbled about my room not being ready (at 4PM) and did I want him to block me to another room. Since I am not an expert on their room types, how am I suppose answer that? I asked if I should choose another and his answer was "another room wouldnt be as good". Not exactly what you want to hear upon arrival. So I waited an hour. The club lounge was nice, but the service was really spotty. The concierge and the waiter were usually involved in conversation. Two long discussions about another employee and uniform problems shouldn't be forced upon the hotel guests. ANother night I came up to use the lounge's computer (which is a lovely feature) and had to wait 15 minutes while the waiter looked some things up online. Another incident is asking the concierge about how the subway system works in LA and her responding "none of us use that". Okay, that is fine. But you are working in a hotel where guests MIGHT use it. Behavior of these employees really made for a poor impression of the hotel. I am surprised that the management of the hotel allows this.

Reviews.Title: “FANTASTIC ART DECO, OLD HOLLYWOOD HOTEL!!!”
Reviews.Author: jody2412
Reviews.Content: Firstly can I say that yes this hotel is an Art Deco style hotel, it does not have flat screen televisions and lots of mod cons or gadgets in the rooms but what it does have is history and glamour. The rooms are spacious and have a vintage feel about them. The beds are roomy and VERY comfortable. The TV isn't flat screened but it works and has all the satellite stations. The breakfast was lovely at the Biltmore it cost 18 dollars for eggs benedict but it was well worth it, I would also recommend the restaurant Smeraldis they do a 3 course meal for 35 dollars each. The parking is expensive but you can park across the road in Pershing square for 12 dollars during the week and 5 dollars at the weekend, it beats the 40 dollars that the hotel charges. Downtown is not scruffy, rough or to be avoided at all costs its quite nice. We hit Starbucks in the mornings which is just around the corner from the hotel, there were a few homeless guys looking for food in bins but they d ont bother you so its nothing to worry about. You do need a car if you want to see all the main attractions in LA if you dont have a car your gonna be stuck. This hotel was fab and I would stay again xx

Reviews.Title: “Unscrupulous Billing Tactics”
Reviews.Author: nycbee
Reviews.Content: After a seven night stay last March (as part of a tour group attending the World Figure Skating Championships) I posted a glowing review of the Biltmore. Yesterday, a shocking charge to my credit card appeared on my billing statement--one that truly brings the ethics of this establishment into question. In August, a full four months after the stay, my credit card billing statement reflected a charge of $645.00 from the Bilmore Hotel relating to that stay. This was inexplicable as my trip was fully prepaid to the travel agent. At hotel check-in I was asked for my credit card number to cover incidental charges that were not the responsibility of the travel agency (certainly a routine request). Upon check-out, I agreed to approximately $80 in incidentals (which was billed to my credit card and promptly paid by me the next month). I never dreamed another $645.00 charge would appear on my credit card months later. I immediately called the hotel and spoke to someone in the accounting department. They contend that the travel agent refused to pay their bil, so the hotel is billing the clients of the company for three of the seven nights of the stay. The above action outrageous, not to say legally baseless. Instead of resolving the dispute with the travel agency, the Biltmore has seen fit to try to squeeze some of the money due them from the travel agent out of their innocent guests. We entered into no contract with the hotel and have no liability for these charges. When I handed my credit card number over to the front desk, it was for the express purpose of paying the incidentals, with the understanding that the rest of my bill was fully satisfied. While I don't rescind my positive impression of the aesthetics and service of the Biltmore, I certainly question the integrity of hotel management and will not stay there in the future.

Reviews.Title: “Older hotel, a little worn but classy”
Reviews.Author: ChicagoTony
Reviews.Content: Room was plenty big except for the small bathroom. The lobby is ornate. What you'd expect from an older hotel that used to hold the academy awards. Ok option if you have to stay downtown.

Reviews.Title: “Polish the Terd”
Reviews.Author: abelloniko
Reviews.Content: $40 for parking, wal-mart bedding, and gaudier furniture than my grandmother's living room. The room was in disrepair and had heavy coats of paint slopped on the walls. The personal items in the bathroom were generic and cheap. I don't mind paying for premium goods and services, but only when I receive a premium product in return. Don't polish a terd, then try to sell it as gold. I've stayed in budget hotels nicer than this.

Reviews.Title: “Classy hotel, transports you to another era.”
Reviews.Author: PMPJ
Reviews.Content: I have lived in L.A. most of my life, and had never been to this hotel until now. While staying here as part of the first leg of a family trip, I felt like I was transported back to the glamour days of old Hollywood. The lobby, bar, and hallways are restored to their original beauty of the 1930's. You can tell the staff is very proud to show you their lovely hotel. The service is attentive and friendly without fawning or being snooty. Classy and elegant. Perfect.

Reviews.Title: “Glamorous and Comfortable”
Reviews.Author: RedBull9
Reviews.Content: I was given a suite remodeled into a single room on the 7th floor. It was huge with a large updated bathroom. The water pressure in the shower was great (which sometimes can be a problem in hotels). The bathroom and bedroom were very clean. The hotel was as pretty as the pictures and really gave the feel of a classic glamorous hotel. The bar was beautiful. Didn't get to try the food. Quiet after 10 pm. Great hotel for less cost. No street parking. Instead of using hotel valet parking $40, I parked in a lot (not ran by hotel) accross the street $12 day and $5 on weekends. Definatly need a car to get around - highway traffic is horrible!

Reviews.Title: “Beware parking trap!”
Reviews.Author: MarkWing
Reviews.Content: This is a beautiful old hotel, truly a grand place from a bygone era. It's lovely to be here and soak in the ambiance and history. Guest rooms are large, and the beds are very comfortable. Beautiful wood shutters in the rooms. Three huge complaints, however: (1) If you're driving, be prepared to pay $40 a day for parking. This was a huge surprise to us, and we felt trapped, with no good alternative. There is no self-parking. (2) These lovely rooms have the tiniest television sets, probably 15 inch screens. If watching TV is important to your hotel stay, this is definitely not the place for you. (3) If you plan on going to sleep before 10 p.m. in the summer, this also is not the place for you. The hotel is located across the street from Pershing Square, where there are live concerts five nights a week. We wondered why there were earplugs provided in the room, and by nightfall, we knew exactly why. It is loud.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty darn good!”
Reviews.Author: OzTraveller81
Reviews.Content: My husband and I recently stayed at the Millenium Biltmore and had a wonderful experience. Everyone working in the hotel was very helpful and professional. There were so many aspects of this hotel that we really enjoyed. It is beautiful, grand and full of history. The room was also very nice. The bathroom is a little small, but we didn't find ourselves spending a lot of time in there, so it wasn't really an issue. The pool was great, as well as the spa and wet and dry saunas. The room service was EXCELLENT, a little pricey, but you get what you pay for! The only thing we weren't that fussed on was the area, as it is a little rough. In saying that though, it's right across the road from Pershing Square train station. It was very easy to get around from there. Another convenient feature was the free internet in the lobby, which you can't say you get everywhere.

Reviews.Title: “Be wary of this hotel!”
Reviews.Author: PeterANDJill
Reviews.Content: My wife and I booked into this hotel for one night on our way back to Australia. The experience we had here was less than enjoyable. Firstly, we arrived late at night due to delayed flights to be told that despite room service being advertised as available, it wasn’t. Oh well we can wait until breakfast we thought! Our hotel room was supposed to be non smoking, but the aroma told us otherwise! Oh well, it’s only for a night we thought! Next morning we checked out of the hotel and arranged to have our bags stored until later that day. When we returned to the hotel we had some last minute purchases to pack and so had our bags retrieved. When my wife opened her suitcase she remarked that a number of zips had been undone and items re-arranged, although nothing had appeared to be removed. That caused me to search my own suitcases and found that an amount of $100 had been removed….I know this to be a fact because I saw the bills when I was packing that morning. I called security and was ‘interogated’ (and I use that word accurately) in the lobby of the hotel. The end result that the security agent required us to write a report and said he would carry out an investigation at some future time!.....all this happened right in front of the bell captain’s desk where those responsible for storing bags were watching with interest. I suggested to the security agent that rather than interrogate us publicly, he should be conducting an immediate search. He simply grinned and wished us a ‘great flight home’. When we returned to Australia I contacted the Hotel security chief who, although prompt with his reply, offered nothing…except an opportunity to meet him when I was next in Los Angeles! Great compensation! The hotel itself has great character…the management and staff certainly don’t. Be careful if staying here!

Reviews.Title: “First class friendly service!”
Reviews.Author: lizziepf
Reviews.Content: We decided to stay in town for a wedding. The hotel was built in 1923 and has a lot of history which is of particular interest to us. Also, the central location to the wedding venue was important. The hotel was able to arrange for taxi service to take us to the venue and return back. Hailing a taxi in LA is not possible. The staff was very professional and friendly. We experienced the afternoon tea and it was the best. The hotel manager stopped by our table to see if we were having and enjoyable experience at the hotel. We were! The ambiance of the hotel was amazing. The room was very comfortable and quiet. We live 45 minutes from downtown but we will definitely stay again for a "mini" vacation.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, good rooms - only letdown is the location”
Reviews.Author: trabug
Reviews.Content: We were booked into the Melliennium Biltmore by our travel agent for a two-night stopover in LA. We had no real problems with the hotel - the lobby is very nice, we had no problems with check-in (even though we were vey early), the rooms were clean and spacious. The hotel has a business centre, a bar and a couple of restaurants, all of which we used without any problems. One morning we ordered room service which was delivered promptly and was very nice. Only drawbacks - firstly the location. Downtown is in the middle of nowhere and you need to catch public transport a long way to get anywhere. It also feels quite unsafe after dark - we opted to stay in. Secondly - we felt by spending a little bit less, we could have had just a nice an experience elsewhere. It's almost as if you feel like you're paying for the faux marble and the high ceilings in the lobby. Our cost for room service was almost extortion. Thirdly - we could hear everything that was going on in our neighbouring hotel room (and there are some things you don't want to hear). If I were to stay in LA again, I'd probably be looking in a different area.

Reviews.Title: “If you appreciate grand and historic lobbies and spaces”
Reviews.Author: GigiMontclair_NJ
Reviews.Content: My daughter and I were on a trip to tour colleges in California. We picked the Biltmore before our visit to Univ. of Southern California. They have great pictures of the old Oscar ceremonies being held there. The lobby, court, grand bar and the event spaces were beautiful. The pool and 3-person hot tub in the dark basement need updating. The rooms were fine for an older hotel, but the hallways look shabby. We got a $99 deal and even with the $40 valet, we thought the hotel was worth a visit. Weddings and graduation celebrations were taking advantage of the lovely festivity spaces. The concierge gave us a great tip for a roof top sushi restaurant just four blocks away.

Reviews.Title: “nice grand old hotel.... always busy”
Reviews.Author: france99
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Biltmore with a friend. Hotel lobby etc are amazing very nice and grand. We had breakfast included which was fine. The staff we met were all very nice and friendly. we were in a twin room, the room was a nice size and beds were comfy however the TV was older than my nan's and out of focus if up close, the rooms could also do with some drawers, we ended up living out of our bags. As two non-coffee drinkers the in room drinks facilities were useless as it was just a coffee maker... keetle with choice of tes/coffee would benefit all. The bathroom was sufficent however could do with a bit of an update. Location wasn't too much of an issue, we were mainly on public transport most of the time and the concierge provided us with detailsof which bus to catch and where from with was handy. We did hire a car for a couple of days but managed to return it to company earlier than expected as the $40 parking fee was more than a days car hire. There was always plenty of people/events in the hotel keeping it busy and allowing lots of people watching! Sorry never made it to pool area so can't comment on that. There is one free internet terminal in the lobby for all to use, however free wireless would be good in all the rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel location not great”
Reviews.Author: anigati
Reviews.Content: Beautiful hotel with exceptional service and good amenities, located in downtown LA and not much to do in area- great if you have hired a car but as we were only in town for 2 nights following on from San Francisco and Las Vegas we needed to be nearer the action - if you are doing this kind of trip and wish to see Universal Studios/Hollywood Boulevard /Stars homes and Santa Monica or any off the beaches etc I would advise staying at Santa Monica beach hotels not downtown LA. LA was a massive disappointment after SAN FRAN and VEGAS but Universal studios (is so much fun and we are 30 +) and a day at Santa Monica beach made up for it, but by staying in downtown we wasted time travelling to see such attractions. San Diego also worth a visit if you have longer visit.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, Historic hotel”
Reviews.Author: One2Few
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing hotel, chalk full of historial value. A good place to stay if interesting in the cultural aspect of downtown los angeles. But if you are looking for fun in the sun head to the Hills. Staff was very friendly and accomodating. Only downfalls, $40 valet parking, no wireless internet.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotels, Room Not So Much. Wouldn't Stay Again.”
Reviews.Author: Spunky_Traveler74
Reviews.Content: The hotel lobby and interior are as beautiful as the pictures, it truly looks like a palace. However my room (king size bed) was not that large and as I've found with other Biltmore's - very old. The TV was not a flat screen but one of those old boxes. There was dust everywhere, the bedskirt looked dirty and I was afraid to use the towels they appeared so old. The bathroom is quite small too. Maybe the other rooms are better but I was not impressed - I definetly prefer modern. If you like the older style hotels with an antique feel, you may like this. Also parking is valet only ($40/day) and there was no option to self-park. Internet connection was not great either from my room. I would not stay here again - lots of better options!

Reviews.Title: “Historic Luxury in the The Middle of Old LA”
Reviews.Author: Bringyourweather
Reviews.Content: I was able to attend the NBA playoffs in May. I chose this hotel mainly because of the close proximity to the Staples Center and price. I was pleasantly suprised to find the Millenium Biltmore in its Regal Splendor from the Doormen to Brass Pineapple wall sconces that adorn the elevator hallways to the intricately painted ceilings that hover above as you stroll through its Grand hallways. Take a step back in time and dip into the indoor pool with its ornate mouldings, hand painted tiles and chaise lounges. Much has been kept from what I say would be its original splendor. The feel of "Old Hollywood" waits around every corner from the vintage photographs ,the grand ballrooms to the well appointed lobby bar. This a great hotel to escape to. The Millenium Biltmore is much more than a place to stay it is an experience.

Reviews.Title: “Not much to complain about”
Reviews.Author: 4Luvmy2
Reviews.Content: I stayed two nights recently for business trip. As a frequently traveler, I get to experience many types of hotels. I had no problems here. The location is great. SERVICE 0 Check in was smooth. I used room service twice and they were timely and accurate. Valet parking was timely and courteous. The ROOM - The room was a nice sizie, comfy bed and clean. The bathroom is a little small with little room for my cosmetics. I would recommend it and stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous hotel, service and location”
Reviews.Author: gato2you
Reviews.Content: This hotel was top of the line. The rooms had old world charm. Located in downtown LA, we were able to use the public transportation right near the hotel. The front desk clerks were most help, especially Elicia Wright. The concierge's were all exceptional, but we found James Russell to be superb. With Jame's help, we were able to see all the sights we had planned to visit. He made it easy!! The inside of the hotel was filled with history and was gorgeous and glamorous. We were excited to return to our hotel after every day's adventure. We would highly recommend this as a must stay if you visit LA. We also found the price reasonable. Thank you. Thank you.

Reviews.Title: “Like a lot of LA, it looks better on the outside than it is inside.”
Reviews.Author: Rob7005b
Reviews.Content: The highlight of staying here was when the supershuttle pulled up and everyone looked round jealously to see who would step out at this stop. That's because the hotel's common areas look fantastic. The lobby and ground floor corridors ooze class and history with wonderful photos and memorabilia of a time gone by when the hotel was at its peak. Unfortunately the rooms and the corridors leading to the rooms have been left behind by time. The rooms are a good size and clean but in need of an upgrade to keep with the rest of the hotel. They lack the modern touches of a top class hotel and the bathroom, while perfectly functional, was a showing its age. The servicing of the rooms was only average, we spent 10 minutes searching for the remote control on arrival finding it under the bed, bed making was done with little care and the tea making facilites were broken in the room we had. Little touches like this hold the hotel back. Nonetheless the room wasn't dirty. The area around the hotel appeared safe and it was only a block away from the metro so getting around was no problem. It's close to the MOCA and Walt Disney Concert Hall and we were able to walk around downtown LA with ease to see many of the sights of the area, Of coure downtown LA is a strange place for a European. To stand in the middle of a large city on a Saturday afternoon and look up and down the street and see no pedestrians and no cars is always a strange experience. If money was spent upgrading the rooms the hotel would truly be back as a great hotel but at present it is merely a good looking shell that lacks heart. Not a bad choice but I'm sure the city has better.

Reviews.Title: “Great classic hotel but the service was even better”
Reviews.Author: GTJimbo
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Millenium Biltmore during the 2nd week of a 2 week business trip to LA. The previous week I had stayed at the Hilton Checkers across the street. That was nice but it was nothing compared to the Millenium. I had read about the beauty of this classic hotel but the reviews do not so it justice. It really feels like a step back in time. The classic architecture is amazing. But what truely impressed me was the service. When I checked in, I noticed that a large convention was in towen and that the hotel was packed with people attending this convention. I asked the man at the front desk for the quietest room he had. He immediately got on the computer and then made a phone call. He informed me that they would upgrade me to the club level as that had the quietest room.
